div.head: A short Treatise of the godly lives, and deaths, of some of the Children of James Oxenham, of Sale Monachorum in Devonshire, Gent: a true and zealous Protestant.
div.p:
APhylosopher on a time being asked, which was the surest way to dye comfortably? presently replyed,▪ To have liv'd vertuously: The Prophet Daniel affirmes it; that the righteous shall shine Dan. 12. as the starres in the firmament: and 'tis no otherwise likely, but that those should shine in Glory, who on Earth were such lights of Puritie and Piety: to doe well is the best method to
end happily; an holy life being the usher in of a blessed death: Marke (saith King David) the upright, and behold the righteous, for the end of that man Psal. 17. is peace.

Such, and no other, were these parties both in their lives, and deaths: a compleat joy, without all question to their Parents. Saint Iohn writing to the Elect Lady, in his Epistle saith, That hee had no greater ioy, than to heare that her Children walked in the truth: and St. Paul doth professe, that such as kept the faith were his ioy and rejoycing: How truely then have the Parents of these, just cause and matter of consolation, when as they were not onely eare but also eye-witnesses of the pious demeanors of their Children; who might say, as once that famous St. Ambrose did to his Auditors: I have not so lived amongst you, as that I am ashamed
to leave you: for certaine, Iesus Christ was and is to all those both in life and death advantage. What an excellent invitation are these to all parents to bring up their children in the feare of God, that being grounded in their younger yeares in the principles of Faith, they may thorow the whole course of their life keep it, and (as St. Peter saith) in the end receive the reward of their Faith, even the salvation of their soules.

In the parish called Sale-monachorum, in the County of Devon, there lives one Iames Oxenham a Gentleman of good worth and quality, who had many Children, one whereof was called John Oxenham, a young man in the vigour, beautie, and flower of his age, about 22. who was of stature comely, and tall, being in height of body sixe foote and an halfe, a very proper person; and for the endowments and gifts of his minde richly qualified; much addicted to pious and religious exercises; (a rare practice in these licentious times) for young men to imitate; thinking it
best to grow in grace betimes, (as King Solomon adviseth) to rem 〈…〉 our Creator in the dayes of our yo 〈…〉
• one knowing how soone Deat •• Ha • binger and fore-runner may summon us all to all to appeare: This young Gentleman fell sicke, who being visited by many of the neighbours during the time of his sicknesse, departed this transitory life on the fifth day of September, 1635. to whom two dayes before hee yeelded up his soule to God, there appeared the likenesse of a bird with a white breast, hovering over him; and so he fitting himselfe for his happy departure, yeelded up his spirit to him that gave it, with manifest and comfortable expressions of his faith in our Lord Jesus Christ: and for the confirmation of this appearance, there are two honest and substantiall men, who were then present,
to take away all sinister suspition and doubt, Robert Woodley and Humphry King, who were not by any rewards hired to speake so; but when they were examined, freely justified the same, both to the Minister of the parish, by the appoyntment of the reverend Father in God, Ioseph Lord Bishop of Exeter.

Not long after but Rebeccah, the sister of the aforesaid Thomazine, aged about eight yeares, to whom about eleven of Clocke of the night appeared the Bird in the same likenesse,
and hovered over her: shee was a virgin of great hopes, and wondrous docible, of a gentle and courteous behaviour to all; shee dyed in a peaceable manner the ninth of Septemb. 1635. prayer having beene publikely by the Minister with the Congregation, made for her recovery, she departed: the witnesses of the aforesaid Apparition, by name Elizabeth Avery, and Mary Stephens.

And she was no sooner dead, but Thomazine a little Child of the aforesaid James Oxenham, and Thomazine his wife, being in a Cradle, fell sicke, over whom did presently appeare the said Bird, in forme as aforesaid, and so she dyed the fifteenth of September, 1635. witnesses to this, the same two afore named, Elizabeth Avery, and Mary Stephens: and what is more, the said bird appeared to Grace, the Grandmother
of the said John, over her death-bed, which said Grace was a vertuous woman, and full of good works, and yeelded her selfe into the hands of her Maker, with great cheerfulnesse and willingnesse, in the yeare of our Redemption, 1618. And to shut up all, there were foure more of the said family and kindred who were sicke, and yet did never see or perceive any such apparition, and recovered their former health speedily, to the glory of God, and comfort of their friends. Now briefely, if there were no such thing, how came some to see it, at severall times, upon the sicknes of severall parties, and all of them did perceive it in one and the same shape? if it were so, how come so many in these times to doubt, nay plainly and flatly to deny that there are any Apparitions now in these times as in former? but to condemne so many sufficient
sober witnesses, lawfully summoned to the confirmation of this particular; what is it but to confine all things to their own bare conceits, and mistrusting opinions: I hold it not therfore amisse, to give the Reader honest satisfaction concerning this one particular thing. I will therefore lay downe some conclusions, to prove the possibility and reallity of such Apparitions even in these latter times; how ever I alwayes will doe it under the censure of better judgements.

First then, none can denie, but before the Law in Abrahams time, there appeared three men to him, and two to Lot, which of all are held to be Angels. Under the Law tis frequently read of sundry Apparitions to the Lords Prophets, and others. Under the Gospell likewise who is so ignorant, but knowes that then there likewise
were sundry Apparitions, as the Holy Ghost came downe in the shape of a Dove: at our Saviours Transfiguration there appeared two men, Moses and Elias. In the Apostles times 'tis not to be questioned, but that Angels appeared to them, as to St. Peter in prison, and before that, to the women after our Saviours Resurrection; & it seemes Apparitions were not onely in those times, but they came also with some affrightment and astonishment of the beholders; so tis read in St. Matthews Gospell, that the women were astonished at the sight of the Angels; so tis said of the Shepheards, they returned with feare and great joy: so also when the Angel appeared to the shepherds, he used this speech to them; feare not, as including thus much, that then men did usually fear such apparitions; 'tis express'd also of our Blessed Lord, that after his resurrection, when he appeared to his Apostles, that hee said to them 'tis I, 'tis not a Spirit, intimating thus much, that then Spirits did appear unto men: when our Saviour walked upon
the Sea, 'tis said of his Disciples, that they were afraid, supposing e it had beene a Spirit, 'twould bee too tedious to recite all examples in this kind: to conclude the first poynt, 'tis cleare, that before and under the Law, as also under the Gospell, and▪ likewise in the Apostles times Apparitions were frequent: but all the question is, whether now, or not? Yes for certaine; I thus prove it: I hope, first none will deny but that there are Angels still, both good, and bad: Secondly, that they are Gods Messengers to men, either for mercy, or judgement: Thirdly, that they doe obey the injunctions laid upon them and dayly execute the will of the supreme Moderator. Fourthly, none can denie but that Angels are Spirits. So Saint Paul calls them, Heb. 1. Ministring Spirits sent out: now lay all these together; first, that they are; secondly, that they bee Gods Agents; thirdly, that they doe what he sends them for: fourthly, that they are all Spirits, and then who can doubt but they appeare likewise? for first, need not the children
of God now as much comfort as ever; who shall bring it if not they? secondly, why are they messengers, unlesse sent out to men? Thirdly, how could they doe their errands, but by appearing? Lastly, what need they be sent, unlesse they came? tis impossible that those famous Martyrs could have so patiently, so comfortably endured all those cruell and exquisite torments as they did, had not Gods Angels ministred unto them helpe and comfort? who can suppose that either the Angels care of Gods Church is lesse than it was? or else their love to men is decreased? or their power abated? or that there is no need now in the last times, which are fullest of persecutions, of their ayd and presence? are we stronger than Daniel, yet he had an Angel? are wee stouter in faith than St. Peter, yet he had such a spirituall Embassador sent to refresh him? are we more than our blessed Lord, and yet tis said, the Angels came and ministred to him? the one of these must needs follow, that either they are not, or else that their office is ceased? but they
are, & their charge is still the same, to pitch their tents about Gods people; and therefore why should they not appeare: this is for good spirits, now for bad: that they may and doe appeare, why not? is not Satan let loose? are not these the last times? doth not he use the wicked Angels to terrifie and punish wicked men: and what doth more terrifie and mak • men agast than what is seen? Belshazzer, if he sees but the hand-writing is suddenly amazed: shall we suppose that all those confessions of wicked men, all those screechings and terrours and affrightments doe proceed from what was never seene? certainly not; if the Devill doth appeare as an Angel of light to deceive, why not as an Angell of darknesse to affright: if hee did present himselfe to our Saviour Christ in a visible forme, in a conspicuous shape, why may he not doe the same, or the like his members? if he useth all meanes to affright and terrifie men, why may he not appeare to them? such who deny there are any apparitions, must either prove (as the Sadduces of
old) that there are no Angels nor Spirits; or else they must say, that they cannot appeare now, which will be hard to do: for first, the wicked neither want will nor malice, and though God limits their power, yet he hath not annihilated it; but doth, as he sees best, give and grant to them power to inflict punishments on men: thats for the first position: it followes now in the second place,

That there are apparitions from the certainty of the sence of seeing: the eye, as it is the noblest of all the sences, so tis the least subject to error; nothing is more certain than what is seene: an eare witnes is not adjudged of that Equivalency, or sufficiencie in determining matters of contest; as an eye witnes. The Prophet David brings in wicked men with this speech in their mouths; Fye on thee we saw it with our eyes, as who should say, that for certaine it must needs then be unquestionably true, and though it be held for a Maxime, that visus fallice circa objectum, (i. e.) that the sight is deceived about obiects; that may be, if it be spoken of their Dimensions,
not realities, or else when the thing propos'd for the obiect is at such a largenesse of distance, that the eie cannot comprehend or reach it: or further, when as that which laid out for the object is of that swiftnes of motion, that it wanting a stability doth by its suddain turnings, and changing windings cozen (as I may so say) and cheat the eye, and thus doe common expert juglers practice: but let the object have Reality, Propinquity, and Stability, and then for certaine the eye will be the surest apprehender of it.

And seeing that color est obiectum visus, (i. e.) that colour is the obiect of the sight: It seldome mistakes black for white, or white for black; but the other sences as they are inferiour, so are they more imperfect than this sence of seeing: this I say, because that concerning this present subject there is principall use made of the eye; now for certaine spirits, though they be incorporeall, and so cannot be felt or touched; yet they are not invisible but that they may bee seene; so then
being that Spirits are visible, and sent, what should hinder, but that when they doe appeare, they may be seen: the former considerations being granted, concerning the nature of the objectt; so that they who suppose, that all apparitions are meerly phantasticall and imaginary, & no waies subject to the sence, must needs overthrow all those apparitions which have beene in all ages, or else make the nature of Spirits to bee different from what they then were; or lastly impute the fault to the imperfection of the sence: all which are alike untrue; and therefore what hinders, that there may not be apparitions good, or bad▪ is not yet discovered.

Thirdly, if apparitions were the onely operations and Chimera's of the phancie, and not reall, then in any great conflicts and tentations, the comfort that Gods Children would feele, should be onely imaginary and phantasticall, not reall: so likewise all the torments and troubles of the soule would have no perpetuity, nor true being; the Imagination so often varying in respect of
the objects variety, and those things which caused or aggravated the torment being not substantiall, but suppositious: so should those everlasting flames of hell not burne really and sensibly the bodies of the wicked condemned thither for Impieties, but hell torments should be onely bug-beares to affright children, & meer conceits; and so like wise those eternall joyes in heaven, and heaven it self should only live, & be in imagination onely: but what strange sequells could these positions produce is easily seen, how weak would the joyes of Gods Children bee? how vaine their hopes? how childish the feares of wicked men? and who would, or need fear the terror of that great Judge?

But briefely, seeing that God hath such instruments of mercy or justice, let the righteous take courage and comfort in all conditions: and let the wicked returne and amend their lewd courses, lest God send out these Instruments in his Justice to punish them for their Rebellions.
